guide.title: Catalyst Reference Manual
guide.abstract: Catalyst reference manual, covering every aspect of Catalyst configuration.

body.p: This document is intended to be a complete reference for all Catalyst targets, spec file options, and all other aspects of Catalyst.

chapter.title: Stage Tarball (stage1, stage2, stage3) Target Reference

body.p: Target description: A stage1 tarball, the base component used for building stage2 and stage3 tarballs.
Requirements for building: A Portage tree snapshot and as well as a stage2 or stage3 "seed" tarball to set up the chroot environment.
The stage1 target uses the following settings:

tr.ti: Sub-architecture catalyst is to build for, e.g. pentium4 or athlon-xp. A stage1 tarball should always use a generic sub-architecture, as it is used to build optimized stages for multiple sub-architectures and is required to run on any of them.
Identifier, i.e. a date or version tag
Target that catalyst is to build, in this case, a stage1 tarball
Build profile catalyst will use, in most cases, default will suffice
Portage profile (/etc/make.profile) that catalyst is to use for the build
Portage snapshot to use, path is relative to ${clst_storedir}/snapshots
Location of seed stage, path relative to ${clst_sharedir}/builds
Hosts used as distcc build slaves

body.p: Target description: A GRP package set. GRP stands for 'Gentoo Reference Platform' and consists of a set of packages and source tarballs, grouped into (optionally) separate directories for easy integration into installation CDs.
Requirements for building: A Portage tree snapshot and a stage3 seed tarball.
The GRP target uses the following settings:

tr.ti: sub-architecture Catalyst is to build for, e.g. pentium4 or athlon-xp
identifier, i.e. a date or version tag
target that Catalyst is to build, in this case, grp
build profile Catalyst will use, in most cases, default will suffice
Portage profile (/etc/make.profile) Catalyst is to use for the build
Portage snapshot to use, path is relative to ${clst_storedir}/snapshots
location of seed stage, path relative to ${clst_sharedir}
hosts used as distcc build slaves
directory structure for the completed GRP build
USE variables to use when building the GRP set
grp/use: gtk2 gnome kde qt bonobo acl
type of GRP build - pkgset will build and package the specified ebuild into a tarball (binary package), and srcset will simply fetch the sources from a Gentoo mirror
list of ebuilds for the appropriate GRP build (srcset, pkgset)
grp/src/packages: pciutils hdparm; grp/packages/packages: pciutils hdparm

body.p: Target description: The tinderbox is a QA target used to build-test a series of packages.
Requirements for building: A Portage tree snapshot and a stage3 seed tarball.
The tinderbox target uses the following settings:

tr.ti: sub-architecture Catalyst is to build for, e.g. pentium4 or athlon-xp
identifier, i.e. a date or version tag
target that Catalyst is to build, in this case, tinderbox
build profile Catalyst will use, in most cases, default will suffice
Portage profile (/etc/make.profile) Catalyst is to use for the build
Portage snapshot to use, path is relative to ${clst_storedir}/snapshots
location of seed stage, path relative to ${clst_sharedir}
hosts used as distcc build slaves
USE flags to be used for the tinderbox build
list of ebuilds for the tinderbox target to build
tinderbox/packages: xorg-x11 kde xmms parted portage

body.p: Usage: Here's how the tinderbox works. The specified seed tarball is used to set up the chroot environment. Then, rsync is used to create a pristine backup of the chroot environment. The firrst package specified in tinderbox/packages is merged, using the USE settings specified in tinderbox/use. Provided it builds correctly, Catalyst uses rsync to restore the chroot environment to its original pristine state. Then, each successive package specified in tinderbox/packages is merged; each merge is followed by a "return to original state" rsync step.

Because of the "return to original state" rsync step, the tinderbox can detect errors in dependencies in certain packages. For a package to compile successfully, it must depend on everything it needs to compile cleanly from a pristine stage3 tarball. Also, this tinderbox testing is actually very efficient when pkgcache is enabled in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf, because pre-built packages will be used to satisfy any dependencies. This means that CPU-hungry builds like xfree will be compiled only once each tinderbox run, provided that pkgcache is enabled.

The tinderbox will continue to build through the complete list of packages specified in tinderbox/packages, even if some packages don't build. A build log is created and stored in [storedir]/tmp/[rel_type]/[subarch]-tinderbox-[version_stamp]/tmp/tinderbox.log. If a package builds correctly, a line will be recorded in this file that contains the name of the package as specified in tinderbox/packages. If a package does not build correctly, a line will be recorded in this file that contains the name of the package, preceded by a "! ". Please note that failures of earlier packages may cause later package builds to fail.
Besides the /tmp/tinderbox.log file created inside the chroot directory, the tinderbox performs no logging. To log the build process, use the script command along with catalyst, as follows:

pre.caption: Using script with Catalyst to log the build process

body.pre: # script Script started, file is typescript # catalyst -f /foo/bar/oni.spec # exit Script done, file is typescript
body.p: Then, view the typescript file in the current directory for a full log of the build process.
Target description: The first preliminary target of LiveCD building, basically a tarball containing a stage3 plus several packages.
Requirements for building: A Portage tree snapshot and a stage3 seed tarball.
The livecd-stage1 target uses the following settings:

tr.ti: sub-architecture Catalyst is to build for, e.g. pentium4 or athlon-xp
identifier, i.e. a date or version tag
target that Catalyst is to build, in this case, livecd-stage1
build profile Catalyst will use, in most cases, default will suffice
Portage profile (/etc/make.profile) Catalyst is to use for the build
Portage snapshot to use, path is relative to ${clst_storedir}/snapshots
location of seed stage, path relative to ${clst_sharedir}
hosts used as distcc build slaves
USE variables used to build the livecd environment
livecd/use: gtk2 kde gnome qt bonobo
list of packages to build and include in the livecd environment
livecd/packages: xorg-x11 qt parted mozilla-firefox gnome

body.impo: livecd MUST be included among the USE variables you specify in the livecd/use variable. Be sure to list sys-apps/baselayout among the packages specified in the livecd/packages variable, as baselayout needs to be re-merged with the livecd USE variable set in order for the LiveCD to boot correctly.

body.p: Target description: This target prepares the LiveCD for general use. A stage2 LiveCD contains a livecd-stage1 plus kernel and initrds to be used for booting the CD image.
Requirements for building: A Portage tree snapshot and a livecd-stage1 seed image.
The livecd-stage2 target uses the following settings:

tr.ti: sub-architecture Catalyst is to build for, e.g. pentium4 or athlon-xp
identifier, i.e. a date or version tag
target that Catalyst is to build, in this case, livecd-stage2
build profile Catalyst will use, in most cases, default will suffice
Portage profile (/etc/make.profile) Catalyst is to use for the build
Portage snapshot to use, path is relative to ${clst_storedir}/snapshots
location of seed stage, path relative to ${clst_sharedir}
hosts used as distcc build slaves
identifiers for all kernels to be available on the LiveCD
kernel ebuild to use for each kernel
full path to the kernel .config used to build the specified kernel
optional tag to add to the specified kernel
list of kernel source dependent ebuilds to be built with the kernel
USE variables used when building the kernel source dependent packages
list of arguments to be passed to genkernel for the specified kernel
list of arguments to be passed to genkernel
type of filesystem to use for the LiveCD, supported types are zisofs, squashfs, cloop, gcloop, and noloop
runscript that Catalyst uses (keep the default value unless you know EXACTLY what you are doing)
archscript that Catalyst uses (keep the default value unless you know EXACTLY what you are doing)
list of directories to empty in the LiveCD environment (used to conserve space)
specific files to remove from the LiveCD environment (used to conserve space)
list of ebuilds to unmerge from the LiveCD environment
location to put the generated .iso file
directory to be copied to the booted livecd fs (not the LiveCD root environment)
full path to the a directory to be overlayed onto the booted LiveCD environment
modules blacklisted from autoloading by hotplug
list of daemons and their respective boot levels to be started in
list of daemons and their respective boot levels to be removed from
full path to the motd to be used by the booted LiveCD environment
which splash package to use, bootsplash or gensplash
script to be run inside of the LiveCD environment (for tweaking the environment, etc)
full path to an xinitrc for use with a XLiveCD
device manager to use on the livecd, either devfs or udev

body.note: runscripts and archscripts: The livecd/runscript and livecd/archscript variables point to shell scripts that handle various chores that require direct shell interaction. For the purposes of the livecd-stage2 target, the archscript and runscript are used to build kernel(s) for the LiveCD, perform some prepping and cleaning of the CD filesystem, place the bootable CD filesystem in a loopback as needed, and set up the LiveCD bootloader.

Using the kernel-related variables in the spec file: For each name in the boot/kernel variable in the spec file (such as gentoo, for example), this target will use genkernel to build a kernel and initrd. With the example boot/kernel entry of gentoo, Catalyst will use the boot/kernel/gentoo/sources setting to determine what kernel sources to merge for this particular kernel build (an example setting would be =sys-kernel/gentoo-dev-sources-2.6.0.) Any USE settings specified in boot/kernel/gentoo/use will be exported to the environment before genkernel is called.

body.p: There are many different options that can be set in catalyst.conf. Find below a detailed explanation of each.
Option Name: ccache
Description: Enables build time ccache support.
Purpose: Speeds up builds dramatically after the first build.
Use: Append ccache to options in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf.
Example: options: ccache
Option Name: pkgcache
Description: Enables caching of .tbz2s.
Purpose: Speeds up builds dramatically after the first build by utilizing prebuilt packages.
Use: Append pkgcache to options in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf.
Example: options: pkgcache
Option Name: distcc
Description: Enables distributed network compiling.
Purpose: Speeds up builds dramatically by utilizing multiple build hosts.
Use: Append distcc to options in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf, and set distcc_hosts in your spec files.
Example: options: distcc
Setting Name: envscript
Description: Enables the definition of any environment variable for use during building.
Purpose: To enable the use of HTTP proxy settings, MAKEOPTS settings, and any other environment settings.
Use: Set envscript=script.sh in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf. An envscript uses the following format:
body.pre: export MAKEOPTS="-j4" export GENTOO_MIRRORS="mymirror" export meep="foo"

body.p: Option Name: storedir
Description: Specifies Catalyst's main working directory.
Purpose: Enables user definition of the working directory.
Use: Set storedir to a specified location in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf
Example: storedir: /home/user/catalyst_storedir
Option Name: sharedir
Description: Specifies the location of Catalyst's main program files and binaries.
Purpose: Enables user definition of the location of Catalyst's main program files and binaries.
Use: Set sharedir to a specified location in /etc/catalyst/catalyst.conf
Example: sharedir: /home/user/catalyst_sharedir
